title: 104_hr2594
content: The Act may be cited as the "Railroad Unemployment Insurance Amendments Act of 1996". It includes a waiting period for unemployment benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to include a waiting period for unemployment benefits, with specific conditions for payment during periods of continuing unemployment. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act now includes a waiting period for benefits, with specific conditions for payment during periods of continuing unemployment. Benefits are not payable for the first 14 days of unemployment, with subsequent days being paid according to the established criteria. A period of continuing unemployment is defined as either a single registration period with more than 4 days of unemployment or a series of consecutive registration periods. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act includes a waiting period for benefits, with specific conditions for payment during periods of continuing unemployment. Benefits are not payable for the first 14 days of unemployment, and a period of continuing unemployment is defined as a series of consecutive registration periods with more than 4 days of unemployment. Additionally, there is a limit on the amount of benefits payable to an eligible employee based on their remuneration. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act specifies that benefits are not payable for the first 14 days of unemployment. The Act also limits the amount of benefits based on the employee's remuneration. Additionally, benefits include the gross amount of remuneration that would have been payable if the employee was ready and willing to work during the registration period. SEC. 3. WAITING PERIOD FOR SICKNESS BENEFITS. Subparagraph (B) of section 2(a)(1) of the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended regarding the payment of sickness benefits. Benefits are payable to qualified employees after the 4th consecutive day of sickness in a period of continuing sickness, with exceptions for the initial registration period. A period of continuing sickness is defined as either consecutive days of sickness from one or more causes or successive days of sickness from a single cause without interruption of more than 90 consecutive days. The period ends when an employee exhausts sickness benefits under subsection (c) of the Act. SEC. 4 amends the maximum daily benefit rate calculation under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act. SEC. 5 sets the maximum number of days for benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to set the maximum number of days for benefits at 130 days for both unemployment and sickness, with a limitation that benefits cannot exceed the employee's compensation in the base year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act sets a maximum of 130 days for benefits for both unemployment and sickness, with benefits capped at the employee's compensation in the base year. Extended benefits are provided for employees with 10 or more years of service who exhaust their normal benefits. Extended sickness benefits may be paid for up to 65 days within an extended benefit period, starting on the first day of unemployment or sickness after exhausting normal benefit rights. The extended benefit period lasts for 7 consecutive 14-day periods and ends when the employee is again eligible for benefits in a new benefit year or reaches the age of 65. An extended benefit period for sickness benefits ends before the employee turns 65, but can continue for paying benefits for unemployment days. Employees with 10+ years of service, not voluntarily retired, and have consecutive days of unemployment or sickness may qualify for accelerated benefits in the next benefit year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act includes provisions for sickness benefits and the determination of age for benefits. Sections 2(h) and 17 of the Act are repealed. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
